elements.content: The reaction between the flexible, bis(pyrazolato)-based ligand 4,4′-bis((3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)­methyl)­biphenyl (H2DMPMB) and late transition metal ions allowed the isolation of the two series of thermally stable metal–organic frameworks [M(DMPMB)] (M = Co, Zn, Cd) and [M 2 (DMPMB)] (M = Cu, Ag). X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) structure determinations demonstrated that the anti conformation adopted by the ligand, juxtaposed to its exo-tetradentate coordination mode, induces the formation of a 3-D architecture with nonpervious 1-D channels in the three isomorphous species [M(DMPMB)] and of corrugated 2-D layers in [Cu 2 (DMPMB)]. Coupling thermogravimetric analyses and variable temperature XRPD highlighted that the five materials are thermally stable at least up to 300 °C, both under nitrogen and in air, the Cd(II) derivative decomposing only at the remarkably high temperature of 500 °C. No thermal event could be detected; all the materials preserve their structural motifs up to decomposition. The adsorption properties of the five compounds were assayed toward N2 at 77 K: while no adsorption was observed for [Cd(DMPMB)], the other species possess estimated BET and Langmuir specific surface areas in the ranges 64(1)–526(3) m2/g and 142(4)–713(27) m2/g, respectively, thus being an example of the interesting phenomenon known as “porosity without pores”. Finally, the luminescence properties of the Zn(II), Cd(II), and Cu(I) derivatives were investigated.

elements.content: The thermally robust coordination polymers [M(DMPMB)] and [Cu 2 (DMPMB)] (M = Zn, Co; H2DMPMB = 4,4′-bis((3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)­methyl)­biphenyl) represent an example of “porosity without pores”. Isolated by a solvothermal route in a closed-pore form, they can switch to an open-pore form in the presence of external stimuli, such as N2 adsorption at 77 K, due to the flexibility granted by the ligand.

elements.content: The hybrid organic–inorganic materials known as metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), above all their porous subset, are continuously gaining ground in scientific research, especially due to their interesting and promising functionalities, e.g., magnetic, optical, electrical, redox, and luminescence properties, as well as, when permanent porosity is present, gas adsorption or separation, catalytic activity, and drug delivery. In the realm of porous MOFs, ultrahigh porosity, provided by architectures with exceptionally large pores and apertures, smart catalysis within the pores, gas adsorption for alternative fuels, gas separation for clean air, and proton conductivity for fuel cell applications constitute some of the current hot topics, which renders it obvious the huge importance that MOFs potentially possess in numerous industrial applications.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The hybrid organic-inorganic materials known as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), above all their porous subset, are continuously gaining ground in scientific research, especially due to their interesting and promising functionalities, e.g., magnetic, optical, electrical, redox, and luminescence properties, as well as, when permanent porosity is present, gas adsorption or separation, catalytic activity, and drug delivery. In the realm of porous MOFs, ultrahigh porosity, provided by architectures with exceptionally large pores and apertures, smart catalysis within the pores, gas adsorption for alternative fuels, gas separation for clean air, and proton conductivity for fuel cell applications constitute some of the current hot topics, which renders it obvious the huge importance that MOFs potentially possess in numerous industrial applications.

elements.content: During the last two decades, and even nowadays, polycarboxylato-containing spacers and nodes based on transition metal ions have been serving as secondary building units for the fabrication of various classes of porous MOFs. Solvothermal processes, microwave irradiation, exploitation of ultrasounds, and electrochemical routes are the most used synthetic methods involved in the production of MOFs. One actual trend to prepare MOFs with tuned chemical and physical properties is the implementation of postsynthetic modifications, particularly on the spacers.

Solvothermal processes, microwave irradiation, exploitation of ultrasounds, and electrochemical routes are the most used synthetic methods involved in the production of MOFs. One actual trend to prepare MOFs with tuned chemical and physical properties is the implementation of postsynthetic modifications, particularly on the spacers.

elements.content: A weakness that may arise when applying polycarboxylato-based MOFs is the lack of stability toward hydrolysis. In light of this, postsynthetic modifications have started being used also to enhance hydrophobicity and render MOFs more resistant against moisture. Recent reports have shown how mixed ligands can lead to MOFs with a higher level of hydrophobicity; as a matter of fact, one of the present trends in the field of MOFs is the design of mixed ligands, aiming at reducing as much as possible the shortcomings arising from polycarboxylato-based materials.

elements.content: As underlined by us and other research groups, the success in obtaining thermally and even chemically stable MOFs resides in the formation of strong metal-to-ligand coordinative bonds, which may be conveniently obtained by employing polyazolato-based spacers.

elements.content: The generation of robust crystal structures with interesting functional properties makes use not only of rigid spacers, but also of flexible ones: in the latter, the donor groups are at the opposite ends of a flexible skeleton, which can take various conformations due to unrestricted rotations about carbon–carbon single bonds. The flexibility of the ligand may have an active role in promoting the flexibility of the resultant framework, conferring it improved features toward, e.g., selective adsorption and separation. Indeed, it has been already demonstrated that, in the presence of an external stimulus, a change in the ligand conformation can trigger the flexibility of the whole network, as in the case of [Cu2(pzdc)2(dpyg)] (pzdc = pyrazine-3,5-dicarboxylate, dpyg = 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)­glycol), for which expansion and contraction phenomena were observed during the adsorption process.

elements.content: In the field of flexible bis(pyrazolato)-based ligands, we have recently demonstrated that 1,4-bis((3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)­methyl)­benzene (H2BDMPZ, Scheme ) may be successfully used to isolate isostructural, cobalt(II)-, and zinc(II)-containing MOFs featuring flexible rhombic channels and displaying “porosity without pores”. In our desire to enlarge the database of thermally stable bis(pyrazolato)-based MOFs possessing functional properties, we decided to assay the coordinative ability of a longer homologous of H2BDMPZ, namely, 4,4′-bis((3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)­methyl)­biphenyl (H2DMPMB, Scheme ). As in the case of H2BDMPZ, the flexibility about the torsion angles hinged at the two methylene groups allows H2DMPMB to adopt anti, syn, or even less symmetric conformations, depending on the relative orientations of the two external “arms”.

In our desire to enlarge the database of thermally stable bis(pyrazolato)-based MOFs possessing functional properties, we decided to assay the coordinative ability of a longer homologous of H2BDMPZ, namely, 4,4'-bis((3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)methyl)biphenyl (H2DMPMB, Scheme ). As in the case of H2BDMPZ, the flexibility about the torsion angles hinged at the two methylene groups allows H2DMPMB to adopt anti, syn, or even less symmetric conformations, depending on the relative orientations of the two external "arms".

elements.content: Almost 50 years have passed since H2DMPMB was reported for the first time. During such a long period, no coordination chemistry was ever studied with this spacer. Therefore, recognizing its promising coordinative potentiality in the fabrication of thermally stable, functional materials, we adopted it to isolate the two series of MOFs [M(DMPMB)] (M = Co, Zn, Cd) and [M 2 (DMPMB)] (M = Cu, Ag). Details about their syntheses, structural features, thermal behavior, adsorption of N2 at 77 K, and photoluminescence are presented hereafter.

elements.content: All the chemicals and reagents were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Co. and used as received, without further purification. All the solvents were distilled prior to use. Before performing the analytical characterization, all the samples were dried in vacuo (50 °C, ∼0.1 Torr) until a constant weight was reached. The IR spectra were recorded from 4000 to 650 cm–1 with a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum 100 instrument by total reflectance on a CdSe crystal. The 1H NMR spectrum of the ligand was recorded with a VXR-300 Varian spectrometer (400 MHz) operating at room temperature and using tetramethylsilane as internal standard. Positive electrospray mass spectrometry was carried out with a Series 1100 MSI detector HP spectrometer, using MeOH as the mobile phase. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed with a Fisons Instruments 1108 CHNS-O elemental analyzer. Melting points were recorded with an SMP3 Stuart instrument equipped with a capillary apparatus. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out in a N2 stream with a Perkin–Elmer STA 6000 Simultaneous thermal analyzer instrument (heating rate: 7 °C/min). Solid state photoluminescence spectra were recorded at room temperature by a Perkin-Elmer LS 45 luminescence spectrometer equipped with a pulsed Xe flash lamp.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All the chemicals and reagents were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Co. and used as received, without further purification. All the solvents were distilled prior to use. Before performing the analytical characterization, all the samples were dried in vacuo (50 °C, ~0.1 Torr) until a constant weight was reached. The IR spectra were recorded from 4000 to 650 cm-1 with a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum 100 instrument by total reflectance on a CdSe crystal. The 1H NMR spectrum of the ligand was recorded with a VXR-300 Varian spectrometer (400 MHz) operating at room temperature and using tetramethylsilane as internal standard. Positive electrospray mass spectrometry was carried out with a Series 1100 MSI detector HP spectrometer, using MeOH as the mobile phase. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed with a Fisons Instruments 1108 CHNS-O elemental analyzer. Melting points were recorded with an SMP3 Stuart instrument equipped with a capillary apparatus. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out in a N2 stream with a Perkin-Elmer STA 6000 Simultaneous thermal analyzer instrument (heating rate: 7 °C/min). Solid state photoluminescence spectra were recorded at room temperature by a Perkin-Elmer LS 45 luminescence spectrometer equipped with a pulsed Xe flash lamp.

elements.content: The synthesis of 4,4′-bis((3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)­methyl)­biphenyl (H2DMPMB) was accomplished improving the two-step approach already proposed in the literature with an optimized procedure to purify the intermediate. Details on the synthetic path adopted and on the characterization of the ligand are available in the (section S1).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 4,4'-Bis((3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)methyl)biphenyl

The synthesis of 4,4'-bis((3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)methyl)biphenyl (H2DMPMB) was accomplished improving the two-step approach already proposed in the literature with an optimized procedure to purify the intermediate. Details on the synthetic path adopted and on the characterization of the ligand are available in the  (section S1).

elements.content: H2DMPMB (0.111 g, 0.30 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of dimethylformamide in a high-pressure glass tube; Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.087 g, 0.30 mmol) was then added. The violet suspension formed was left under stirring at 130 °C for 24 h. The violet precipitate obtained was filtered off, washed twice with methanol, and then dried in vacuo. Yield: 88%. [Co(DMPMB)] is insoluble in alcohols, dimethyl sulfoxide, acetone, acetonitrile, dimethylformamide, and water. IR (cm–1): 3100–3000(vw) ν(C–Haromatic), 3000–2800(m) ν(CH3, CH2), 1504(s) ν(CC+CN). Elemental analysis calc. for C24H24CoN4 (FW = 427.41 g/mol): C, 67.44; H, 5.66; N, 13.11%. Found: C, 67.02; H, 5.63; N, 12.65%. Alternatively, compound [Co(DMPMB)] could be obtained by using cobalt(II) acetate as the source of metal ions.

elements.content: Powdered, polycrystalline samples of the species H2DMPMB, [M(DMPMB)] (M = Co, Zn, Cd) and [M 2 (DMPMB)] (M = Cu, Ag), not containing single crystals, were ground in an agate mortar. Then, they were deposited in the hollow of an aluminum-framed sample holder equipped with a quartz zero-background plate. For all the species, preliminary data acquisitions were carried out at room temperature in the 2θ range of 3–35°, with steps of 0.02°, on a Bruker AXS D8 Advance diffractometer, equipped with Ni-filtered Cu–Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å), with a Lynxeye linear position-sensitive detector and with the following optics: primary beam Soller slits (2.3°), fixed divergence slit (0.5°), receiving slit (8 mm). A visual inspection of these preliminary data suggested that the Co(II), Zn(II), and Cd(II) derivatives are isomorphous. To carry out the structure determinations, another set of diffraction data was collected by means of overnight scans in the 2θ range of 5–105°, with steps of 0.02°. Peak search, followed by indexing through the singular value decomposition approach implemented in TOPAS-R, allowed the detection of the approximate unit cell parameters of all the species, but the Ag(I) derivative. The space groups were assigned on the basis of the systematic absences. Indexing and space group assignment supported the hypothesis of isomorphism among the Co(II)-, Zn(II)-, and Cd(II)-based compounds. Prior to the structure solution, unit cells and space groups were controlled by means of Le Bail refinements. The structure solutions were performed by the simulated annealing technique, implemented in TOPAS-R, employing an idealized model for the crystallographically independent portion of the ligand. Flexibility at the methylene junction was allowed: the torsional angles around the exocyclic C–C bonds were allowed to vary; the exocyclic C–C–C angle was allowed refine with respect to the ideal value of 109.5°. The final refinements were carried out by the Rietveld method, maintaining the rigid body introduced at the solution stage. The C–C single bond values were allowed to refine in the range 1.50–1.54 Å. The peak shapes were described with the fundamental parameters approach. The background was modeled by a Chebyshev polynomial. One, isotropic thermal parameter was assigned to the metal atoms (B M) and refined; lighter atoms were given a B iso = B M + 2.0 Å2 isotropic thermal parameter. The peak shape anisotropy was modeled with the aid of spherical harmonics in the case of H2DMPMB and of the Co(II), Zn(II), and Cd(II) derivatives. Only in the case of the Cd(II)- and Cu(I)-containing species, data collections were performed also at 150 °C using a custom-made sample heater (Officina Elettrotecnica di Tenno, Ponte Arche, Italy), equipped with a Peltier cell and mounted onto the D8 diffractometer. The samples were deposited in the hollow of an aluminum-framed sample holder equipped with a silicon zero-background plate. The data were collected overnight in the 2θ range of 5–95°, with steps of 0.02°, and with the same instrumental setup described above.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Powder Diffraction Structural Analysis

Powdered, polycrystalline samples of the species H2DMPMB, [M(DMPMB)] (M = Co, Zn, Cd) and [M  2  (DMPMB)] (M = Cu, Ag), not containing single crystals, were ground in an agate mortar. Then, they were deposited in the hollow of an aluminum-framed sample holder equipped with a quartz zero-background plate. For all the species, preliminary data acquisitions were carried out at room temperature in the 2θ range of 3-35°, with steps of 0.02°, on a Bruker AXS D8 Advance diffractometer, equipped with Ni-filtered Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å), with a Lynxeye linear position-sensitive detector and with the following optics: primary beam Soller slits (2.3°), fixed divergence slit (0.5°), receiving slit (8 mm). A visual inspection of these preliminary data suggested that the Co(II), Zn(II), and Cd(II) derivatives are isomorphous. To carry out the structure determinations, another set of diffraction data was collected by means of overnight scans in the 2θ range of 5-105°, with steps of 0.02°. Peak search, followed by indexing through the singular value decomposition approach implemented in TOPAS-R, allowed the detection of the approximate unit cell parameters of all the species, but the Ag(I) derivative. The space groups were assigned on the basis of the systematic absences. Indexing and space group assignment supported the hypothesis of isomorphism among the Co(II)-, Zn(II)-, and Cd(II)-based compounds. Prior to the structure solution, unit cells and space groups were controlled by means of Le Bail refinements. The structure solutions were performed by the simulated annealing technique, implemented in TOPAS-R, employing an idealized model for the crystallographically independent portion of the ligand. Flexibility at the methylene junction was allowed: the torsional angles around the exocyclic C-C bonds were allowed to vary; the exocyclic C-C-C angle was allowed refine with respect to the ideal value of 109.5°. The final refinements were carried out by the Rietveld method, maintaining the rigid body introduced at the solution stage. The C-C single bond values were allowed to refine in the range 1.50-1.54 Å. The peak shapes were described with the fundamental parameters approach. The background was modeled by a Chebyshev polynomial. One, isotropic thermal parameter was assigned to the metal atoms (B M) and refined; lighter atoms were given a B iso = B M + 2.0 Å2 isotropic thermal parameter. The peak shape anisotropy was modeled with the aid of spherical harmonics in the case of H2DMPMB and of the Co(II), Zn(II), and Cd(II) derivatives. Only in the case of the Cd(II)- and Cu(I)-containing species, data collections were performed also at 150 °C using a custom-made sample heater (Officina Elettrotecnica di Tenno, Ponte Arche, Italy), equipped with a Peltier cell and mounted onto the D8 diffractometer. The samples were deposited in the hollow of an aluminum-framed sample holder equipped with a silicon zero-background plate. The data were collected overnight in the 2θ range of 5-95°, with steps of 0.02°, and with the same instrumental setup described above.

Variable-temperature X-ray powder diffraction (VT-XRPD) experiments were performed on the species [M(DMPMB)] (M = Co, Zn, Cd) and [M 2 (DMPMB)] (M = Cu, Ag) to highlight their response to temperature increases. The experiments were carried out in air using a custom-made sample heater (Officina Elettrotecnica di Tenno, Ponte Arche, Italy), mounted onto the D8 diffractometer equipped with the same setup described above. Powdered polycrystalline samples of the five materials were ground in an agate mortar and deposited in the hollow of an aluminum sample holder. The diffraction data were acquired in a sensible, low-angle 2θ range, heating in situ, with steps of 20 °C, from 30 °C up to decomposition. Except for the silver(I) derivative, the data acquired before a significant loss of crystallinity took place were treated by parametric Le Bail refinements to depict the variation of the unit cell parameters as a function of the temperature. When comparing the TG and VT-XRPD results, the reader must be aware that the thermocouple of the VT-XRPD setup is not in direct contact with the sample, this determining a slight difference in the temperature at which the same event is detected by the two techniques. The TG temperatures have to be considered as more reliable.

elements.content: Gas adsorption isotherms for pressures in the range of 0–1 bar were measured by the volumetric method using a Beckman Coulter SA 3100 Surface Area & Pore Size Analyzer instrument. A sample of ca. 100 mg of as-synthesized material was introduced into a preweighed analysis tube (9 mm diameter, 9 cm3 bulb), capped with a gastight transeal to prevent entrance of atmosphere oxygen and of moisture during transfer and weighing. The samples were evacuated under dynamic vacuum (10–5 bar) at 150 °C, until a constant weight was achieved. The analysis tube was then weighed again to determine the mass of the evacuated sample. For all the isotherms, warm and cold free space correction measurements were performed using ultra high purity He gas (UHP grade 5.0, 99.999% purity). N2 isotherms at 77 K were measured in a liquid nitrogen bath using a UHP-grade gas source.

elements.content: The synthesis of 4,4′-bis((3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)­methyl)­biphenyl (H2DMPMB) was accomplished improving the two-step approach already proposed in the literature with an optimized procedure to purify the intermediate. As depicted in , by reacting acetylacetone 1 and diphenyl-4,4′-dicarbaldehyde 2 (prepared according to a modified procedure with respect to the previously reported one) in acetonitrile under reflux, in the presence of trimethylchlorosilane and sodium iodide, the intermediate 4,4′-bis((β-diketone)­methyl)­biphenyl 3 is formed. After its purification, the reaction of the intermediate 3 with an excess of hydrazine hydrate in ethanol at room temperature promotes, by simple condensation, the formation of 1,4-bis((3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)­methyl)­biphenyl 4 as a white, air-stable solid. In its 1-H NMR spectrum, two signals are detectable for the nonequivalent methyl groups, likely due to the lack of fluxionality, or to a slow interchange of the N–H proton between the two heterocyclic nitrogen atoms. As suggested by IR spectroscopy (), in the solid state adjacent H2DMPMB molecules interact by means of N–H···N hydrogen bond interactions.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Crystal Structure Analysis of the Ligand H2DMPMB

The synthesis of 4,4'-bis((3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)methyl)biphenyl (H2DMPMB) was accomplished improving the two-step approach already proposed in the literature with an optimized procedure to purify the intermediate. As depicted in , by reacting acetylacetone 1 and diphenyl-4,4'-dicarbaldehyde 2 (prepared according to a modified procedure with respect to the previously reported one) in acetonitrile under reflux, in the presence of trimethylchlorosilane and sodium iodide, the intermediate 4,4'-bis((β-diketone)methyl)biphenyl 3 is formed. After its purification, the reaction of the intermediate 3 with an excess of hydrazine hydrate in ethanol at room temperature promotes, by simple condensation, the formation of 1,4-bis((3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)methyl)biphenyl 4 as a white, air-stable solid. In its 1-H NMR spectrum, two signals are detectable for the nonequivalent methyl groups, likely due to the lack of fluxionality, or to a slow interchange of the N-H proton between the two heterocyclic nitrogen atoms. As suggested by IR spectroscopy (), in the solid state adjacent H2DMPMB molecules interact by means of N-H⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bond interactions.

elements.content: The H2DMPMB ligand crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. In its crystal structure, the molecules are located on crystallographic inversion centers. As a consequence, the two 4-methylene-3,5-dimethylpyrazole moieties adopt an idealized C 2h anti conformation, pointing away from the inner aromatic core in opposite directions (Figure a). As pointed out by IR spectroscopy, nearby molecules are involved in N–H···N hydrogen bonds (N···N 2.89(6) Å, Figure b), which contribute to the cohesiveness of the overall crystal structure, by defining 2-D layers running orthogonally to the [102] direction.

elements.content: In order to discover the best route for isolating each target material, several screening reactions were conducted by changing conditions such as solvents, temperature, time, and reagents concentration. IR spectroscopy was routinely applied in order to monitor the progress of all the screening trials: focusing the attention on the complete disappearance of the N–H stretching bands gave indications about the targeted stoichiometric formulations.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Species [M(DMPMB)] and [M  2  (DMPMB)] 

In order to discover the best route for isolating each target material, several screening reactions were conducted by changing conditions such as solvents, temperature, time, and reagents concentration. IR spectroscopy was routinely applied in order to monitor the progress of all the screening trials: focusing the attention on the complete disappearance of the N-H stretching bands gave indications about the targeted stoichiometric formulations.

elements.content: The isolation of the homoleptic coordination polymers [M(DMPMB)] (M = Co, Zn, Cd) and [Cu 2 (DMPMB)] was successfully accomplished by following a solvothermal route. As a matter of fact, species [M(DMPMB)] and [Cu 2 (DMPMB)] could be obtained in high-pressure glass tubes at 130 °C, under autogenous pressure, by reacting metal(II) nitrates or acetates and H2DMPMB in dimethylformamide for 24 h, as it was already experienced with the previously reported BDMPZ-based species. Worthy of note, as in the case of [Cu2(BDMPZ)], the high temperature reaction between a copper(II) salt and H2DMPMB triggers the reduction of Cu(II) to Cu(I). Indeed, the Cu(II)-containing, green suspension observed at the beginning of the reaction is gradually transformed into a Cu(I)-based, white precipitate. Reduction of Cu(II)-based, pyrazole-containing complexes promoted by heating has already been observed, especially when the penta-atomic ring is 3,5-disubstituted, and may be tentatively attributed to the partial oxidation of pyrazole.

elements.content: The homoleptic derivative [Ag 2 (DMPMB)] was isolated by following a different route: employing silver chloride as the source of silver(I) ions in the presence of ammonia, the resulting cationic complex [Ag(NH3)2]+ reacts at room temperature with H2DMPMB dissolved in methanol, yielding [Ag 2 (DMPMB)] in the form of white powders. A similar synthetic strategy, involving ammonia solutions of silver(I) salts, was successfully applied, e.g., to prepare the two supramolecular isomers [Ag2(Me4BPZ)] (Me4BPZ = 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethyl-4,4′-bis(pyrazolyl)).

elements.content: All the isolated species precipitate in high yields as air- and moisture-stable polycrystalline powders, insoluble in water and in the most common solvents, this observation suggesting their polymeric nature. Their IR spectra (), consistent with the proposed formulations, present similar absorption bands. In particular, the absence of N–H stretching bands indicates complete deprotonation of the organic spacer along with the formation of metal-bridging bis(pyrazolato) dianions, as eventually confirmed by the XRPD structure determinations.

Crystal Structures Analysis

All the crystal and molecular structures discussed hereafter have been retrieved from state-of-the-art powder diffraction structure determination methods applied to laboratory data. Relevant crystallographic details are gathered in Table , while the main geometrical parameters are provided throughout the text and in the figure captions.

elements.content: As the three species [M(DMPMB)] (M = Co, Zn, Cd) are isomorphous and isostructural, their crystal and molecular structures will be discussed jointly in the following. The [M(DMPMB)] materials crystallize in the orthorhombic space group Pccn. The asymmetric unit contains one metal ion and one spacer, both lying on special positions (a crystallographic 2-fold axis and an inversion center, respectively). Overall, the three crystal structures are characterized by a polymeric 3-D architecture, the secondary building units of which are MN4 nodes and exo-tetradentate spacers. More in detail, each metal ion is coordinated by four nitrogen atoms belonging to four pyrazolato groups and defining a distorted tetrahedral stereochemistry (Figure a). Not unexpectedly, each pyrazolato ring adopts an exo-bidentate coordination mode, bridging adjacent metal ions 3.67(1)–3.895(4) Å apart, to form 1-D chains of collinear metal centers (Figure a) running along the crystallographic axis c. The copresence of two penta-atomic rings on the same spacer, and the fact that they adopt an anti conformation with respect to the inner skeleton of the ligand, allows cross-linking of the metal chains along two different directions to yield a nonporous 3-D network (Figures b and ). In spite of the absence of porosity, 1-D nonpervious channels of rhombic shape can be appreciated along the crystallographic axis a, their walls being decorated by the ligands (Figure b). Worthy of note, the same structural motif has been previously observed in the case of the [M(BDMPZ)] series (M = Co, Zn, Cd), constructed with the shorter BDMPZ2– spacer. Hence, [M(DMPMB)] and [M(BDMPZ)] constitute, as originally proposed by Yaghi, an isoreticular family. The rhombic motif envisaged in compounds [M(DMPMB)] inevitably recalls those present, e.g., in Férey’s metal hydroxy-terephthalates of the MIL-53 series, and in the [M(BDP)] derivatives (M = Ni, Co; H2BPD = 1,4-bis(1H-pyrazol-4-yl)­benzene)). In spite of this similarity, in the two series [M(DMPMB)] and [M(BDMPZ)], both at room and at high temperature (see below), a closed-pore form is available, in which no cavities, channels, or interstices can be envisaged capable to host, without distortions, probe molecules. In principle, this feature should not prevent gas adsorption: external stimuli such as temperature, pressure, or entering gas molecules may induce pore-opening/pore-closing processes.

Crystal and Molecular Structures of the Species [M(DMPMB)]

As the three species [M(DMPMB)] (M = Co, Zn, Cd) are isomorphous and isostructural, their crystal and molecular structures will be discussed jointly in the following. The [M(DMPMB)] materials crystallize in the orthorhombic space group Pccn. The asymmetric unit contains one metal ion and one spacer, both lying on special positions (a crystallographic 2-fold axis and an inversion center, respectively). Overall, the three crystal structures are characterized by a polymeric 3-D architecture, the secondary building units of which are MN4 nodes and exo-tetradentate spacers. More in detail, each metal ion is coordinated by four nitrogen atoms belonging to four pyrazolato groups and defining a distorted tetrahedral stereochemistry (Figure a). Not unexpectedly, each pyrazolato ring adopts an exo-bidentate coordination mode, bridging adjacent metal ions 3.67(1)-3.895(4) Å apart, to form 1-D chains of collinear metal centers (Figure a) running along the crystallographic axis c. The copresence of two penta-atomic rings on the same spacer, and the fact that they adopt an anti conformation with respect to the inner skeleton of the ligand, allows cross-linking of the metal chains along two different directions to yield a nonporous 3-D network (Figures b and ). In spite of the absence of porosity, 1-D nonpervious channels of rhombic shape can be appreciated along the crystallographic axis a, their walls being decorated by the ligands (Figure b). Worthy of note, the same structural motif has been previously observed in the case of the [M(BDMPZ)] series (M = Co, Zn, Cd), constructed with the shorter BDMPZ2- spacer. Hence, [M(DMPMB)] and [M(BDMPZ)] constitute, as originally proposed by Yaghi, an isoreticular family. The rhombic motif envisaged in compounds [M(DMPMB)] inevitably recalls those present, e.g., in Férey's metal hydroxy-terephthalates of the MIL-53 series, and in the [M(BDP)] derivatives (M = Ni, Co; H2BPD = 1,4-bis(1H-pyrazol-4-yl)benzene)). In spite of this similarity, in the two series [M(DMPMB)] and [M(BDMPZ)], both at room and at high temperature (see below), a closed-pore form is available, in which no cavities, channels, or interstices can be envisaged capable to host, without distortions, probe molecules. In principle, this feature should not prevent gas adsorption: external stimuli such as temperature, pressure, or entering gas molecules may induce pore-opening/pore-closing processes.

elements.content: [Cu 2 (DMPMB)] crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21 /c. The asymmetric unit contains two metal ions and one ligand, all in general positions. Overall, the crystal structure of [Cu 2 (DMPMB)] contains corrugated 2-D layers, the secondary building units of which are MN2 nodes and exo-tetradentate spacers. More in detail, each metal ion is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms belonging to two pyrazolato groups and defining a digonal stereochemistry (Figure a). Each pyrazolato moiety shows an exo-bidentate coordination mode, bridging metal ions 3.20(2) or 3.28(2) Å apart, to form 1-D zigzag chains of metal ions (Figure a) running along the crystallographic axis c. The two pyrazolato rings on the same linker, adopting also in the present case an anti conformation with respect to the inner skeleton, allows pillaring of adjacent metal chains to yield corrugated 2-D layers (Figure b), stacking along the crystallographic axis b (). Obviously, the coordination number of Cu(I), reduced with respect to that observed in the series [M(DMPMB)], is responsible for the formation of a 2-D, rather than a 3-D, polymeric network. Also in this case, we are in the presence of a nonporous structure, so that to explain the observed adsorption performances (see below) we must invoke an active role of the flexible ligand in promoting the flexibility of the overall framework.

Crystal and Molecular Structure of the Species [Cu  2  (DMPMB)] 

 [Cu  2  (DMPMB)] crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21 /c. The asymmetric unit contains two metal ions and one ligand, all in general positions. Overall, the crystal structure of [Cu  2  (DMPMB)] contains corrugated 2-D layers, the secondary building units of which are MN2 nodes and exo-tetradentate spacers. More in detail, each metal ion is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms belonging to two pyrazolato groups and defining a digonal stereochemistry (Figure a). Each pyrazolato moiety shows an exo-bidentate coordination mode, bridging metal ions 3.20(2) or 3.28(2) Å apart, to form 1-D zigzag chains of metal ions (Figure a) running along the crystallographic axis c. The two pyrazolato rings on the same linker, adopting also in the present case an anti conformation with respect to the inner skeleton, allows pillaring of adjacent metal chains to yield corrugated 2-D layers (Figure b), stacking along the crystallographic axis b (). Obviously, the coordination number of Cu(I), reduced with respect to that observed in the series [M(DMPMB)], is responsible for the formation of a 2-D, rather than a 3-D, polymeric network. Also in this case, we are in the presence of a nonporous structure, so that to explain the observed adsorption performances (see below) we must invoke an active role of the flexible ligand in promoting the flexibility of the overall framework.

elements.content: On comparing the local geometrical features of the five crystal structures presented (see ), a substantial constancy of the conformational parameters can be observed, particularly as regards the three [M(DMPMB)] MOFs. Due to evident steric hindrance, the pyrazolato rings show an uncommon twist, already observed, for example, in [M(BDMPZ)] and in the series [M2(DMPZ)4(HDMPZ)2] (HDMPZ = 3,5-dimethylpyrazole; M = Co, Zn). As a result of the twist, the torsion angles involving the methylene group are somewhat different than in the case of the ligand alone. Moreover, the values of the M–N–N–M torsion angles fall in the range −55/–59° (to be compared to an ideal value of 0°, as observed in most of the bis- and tris(pyrazolato)-based coordination polymers known). Possibly due to the lower coordination number of the metal center, the steric hindrance is less pronounced in the case of [Cu 2 (DMPMB)]; hence the pyrazolato rings are only slightly twisted, the values of the M–N–N–M torsion angles falling, at room temperature, around 2°.

elements.content: The thermal behavior of compounds [M(DMPMB)] (M = Co, Zn, Cd) and [M 2 (DMPMB)] (M = Cu, Ag) was investigated by coupling thermogravimetric analyses, carried out under nitrogen in the temperature range 25–700 °C with a heating rate of 7 °C/min, and variable-temperature X-ray powder diffraction (VT-XRPD), performed in air. As a representative example, Figure collects the TG trace, the VT-XRPD data, and their subsequent parametric Le Bail refinement for the Zn(II) derivative. For all the other species, the reader is redirected to . On the whole, the five species possess a non-negligible thermal stability, not only under nitrogen, but also in air, surviving at least up to 300 °C, an important aspect to be ascertained in view of specific practical applications. Another crucial feature when certain practical applications are invoked is the fact that no thermal event could be detected prior to decomposition, the five materials thus preserving their structural motif when stimulated by temperature. An outstanding thermal stability is shown by [Cd(DMPMB)], whose decomposition onset is located at 500 °C. A similar result was observed in the case of the congener [Cd(BDMPZ)]. The remarkable robustness of the DMPMB-based coordination polymers confirms once again the crucial role of the bis(pyrazolato)-based spacers in establishing strong metal-to-ligand coordination bonds, imparting a great thermal stability to the corresponding polymeric networks.

Another crucial feature when certain practical applications are invoked is the fact that no thermal event could be detected prior to decomposition, the five materials thus preserving their structural motif when stimulated by temperature. An outstanding thermal stability is shown by [Cd(DMPMB)], whose decomposition onset is located at 500 °C. A similar result was observed in the case of the congener [Cd(BDMPZ)]. The remarkable robustness of the DMPMB-based coordination polymers confirms once again the crucial role of the bis(pyrazolato)-based spacers in establishing strong metal-to-ligand coordination bonds, imparting a great thermal stability to the corresponding polymeric networks.

elements.content: According to their TG traces (Figures and ), the Co-, Zn-, and Cd-containing materials are stable up to 450 °C, 450 °C, and 500 °C, respectively, temperatures at which a progressive decomposition starts. In all of the three cases, at the end of the heating process a black residue is recovered, likely (but not exclusively) belonging to carbonaceous species. Incidentally, the observed decomposition temperatures of the Co(II)- and Zn(II)- derivatives are higher than those detected for their congeners [M(BDMPZ)], the decomposition onsets of which were located at 400 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Behavior of the Species [M(DMPMB)] 

According to their TG traces (Figures  and ), the Co-, Zn-, and Cd-containing materials are stable up to 450 °C, 450 °C, and 500 °C, respectively, temperatures at which a progressive decomposition starts. In all of the three cases, at the end of the heating process a black residue is recovered, likely (but not exclusively) belonging to carbonaceous species. Incidentally, the observed decomposition temperatures of the Co(II)- and Zn(II)- derivatives are higher than those detected for their congeners [M(BDMPZ)], the decomposition onsets of which were located at 400 °C.

elements.content: Worthy of note, the high thermal stability observed under nitrogen is maintained also in air, as witnesses by the VT-XRPD experiments. Parametric Le Bail treatments of the VT-XRPD data acquired before the loss of crystallinity demonstrate that the unit cell axes undergo a similar behavior in all of the three cases (Figures , ). As a matter of fact, b is the most affected axis, its steady increase being directly proportional to the temperature raise. On the contrary, the lengths of a and c undergo only a moderate increment. Overall, thermal expansion is at work, as the unit cell volume increases in all the three cases (of ca. 2.1, 3.1, and 4.5% for [Co(DMPMB)], [Zn(DMPMB)], and [Cd(DMPMB)], respectively).

elements.content: The small modification of the unit cell axis c is not unexpected, and it is reasonably due to the fact that [001] is the direction along which the 1-D metal chains run, the length of c being dictated by the length of the pyrazolato-bridged M···M vectors. The slight variation of a and the concomitant, high increase of b might be in principle attributed to the flexibility of the ligand, which can rearrange about the methylene group. To verify this hypothesis, an overnight scan was performed at 150 °C on the Cd(II) derivative. The Rietveld refinement of the data acquired at high temperature reveals that a certain modification of the torsion angles involving the methylene group is at work (), together with a variation of the geometrical parameters involving the metal ions ().

elements.content: As witnessed by its TG trace (), [Cu 2 (DMPMB)] is stable up to 420 °C, the temperature at which the onset of the decomposition process is set. At the end of the thermal treatment, a dark brown residue is recovered. Also in this case the H2DMPMB-based derivative is more stable than the H2BDMPZ-containing congener, the decomposition onset of which was observed at 300 °C. The material possesses the same thermal stability also in air, as demonstrated by the VT-XRPD experiment. As highlighted by the parametric treatment of the VT-XRPD data (), thermal expansion is at work: due to the increment of both a and b, the unit cell volume increases of about 3.3% in the temperature range 30–310 °C. On the contrary, the unit cell axis c is almost unaffected by the thermal treatment, as it varies of only −0.1%: also in this case, this is the unit cell axis parallel to which the 1-D metal chains run. To clarify the origin of the variation of a and b, an overnight scan was performed at 150 °C on this material. The Rietveld refinement of the data acquired at high temperature reveals, with respect to room temperature, moderate modifications of the torsion angles involving the methylene groups () and of the geometrical parameters involving the metal center ().

All of the four materials exhibit Type I adsorption isotherms with a sharp knee at low relative pressures (p/p 0 ≈ 0.01), corresponding to the filling of the micropores, followed by a plateau, suggesting that the permanent porosity of the samples is mainly due to micropores of quite uniform size. The presence, in all of the isotherms, of a hysteresis loop might be indicative of textural mesoporosity arising from interparticle, mesoporous voids.

The presence, in all of the isotherms, of a hysteresis loop might be indicative of textural mesoporosity arising from interparticle, mesoporous voids.

elements.content: In the pressure range assayed, the N2 adsorption capacity of the samples increases along the sequence [Ag 2 (DMPMB)] < [Cu 2 (DMPMB)] < [Zn(DMPMB)] < [Co(DMPMB)]. Fitting the N2 isotherms, we estimated BET and Langmuir specific surface areas in the ranges 64(1)–526(3) m2/g and 142(4)–713(27) m2/g, respectively (Table ). The absence of adsorption in the case of [Cd(DMPMB)] implies that, despite its isomorphism to [Co(DMPMB)] and [Zn(DMPMB)] at room and high temperature, its framework does not undergo the structural changes reasonably experienced by [Co(DMPMB)] and [Zn(DMPMB)] upon adsorption of nitrogen at 77 K. Worthy of note, the same situation had been observed also in the case of its isoreticular congener [Cd(BDMPZ)]. The persistence of such phenomenon is well explained by Cirera and co-workers, whose extensive stereochemical analysis reveals that the stereochemical flexibility of the ZnN4 nodes is higher than that of the Cd(II) analogues.

elements.content: Finally, [Co(DMPMB)], [Zn(DMPMB)], and [Cu 2 (DMPMB)] may constitute a new entry in the emerging and still under-investigated category of “porosity without pores” materials, in which flexibility, prompted by an ad hoc external stimulus, brings about permanent porosity, as already evidenced in the case of previously reported MOFs, such as [M(BDMPZ)] (M = Zn, Co), and [Cu(Hoxonato)(bpy)0.5]·1.5H2O (H3oxonic = 4,6-dihydroxy-1,3,5-triazine-2-carboxylic acid; bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine).

elements.content: Numerous coordination polymers containing d10 metals are well-known to exhibit interesting photoluminescence properties. In the light of this, solid state measurements at room temperature were carried out on species [Zn(DMPMB)], [Cd(DMPMB)], and [Cu 2 (DMPMB)]. Preliminary tests revealed that they respond differently when exposed to UV irradiation (Figure top): when excited at 365 nm, [Zn(DMPMB)], [Cd(DMPMB)], and [Cu 2 (DMPMB)] exhibit an intense blue, near-white, and orange luminescence emission, respectively. More in detail (Figure bottom), when excited at 365 nm, the Zn(II) derivative is characterized by a single, broad emission band in the near-UV region, centered at λmax = 440 nm. When excited at 254 nm, the Cd(II) homologous gives a single and broad emission band with a maximum at 335 nm. Finally, when excited at 365 nm, the Cu(I) species gives one broad band in the visible region, with a maximum at 597 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence Properties

Numerous coordination polymers containing d10 metals are well-known to exhibit interesting photoluminescence properties. In the light of this, solid state measurements at room temperature were carried out on species [Zn(DMPMB)], [Cd(DMPMB)], and [Cu  2  (DMPMB)]. Preliminary tests revealed that they respond differently when exposed to UV irradiation (Figure  top): when excited at 365 nm, [Zn(DMPMB)], [Cd(DMPMB)], and [Cu  2  (DMPMB)] exhibit an intense blue, near-white, and orange luminescence emission, respectively. More in detail (Figure  bottom), when excited at 365 nm, the Zn(II) derivative is characterized by a single, broad emission band in the near-UV region, centered at λmax = 440 nm. When excited at 254 nm, the Cd(II) homologous gives a single and broad emission band with a maximum at 335 nm. Finally, when excited at 365 nm, the Cu(I) species gives one broad band in the visible region, with a maximum at 597 nm.

elements.content: Photoluminescence manifested by [Zn(DMPMB)], [Cd(DMPMB)], and [Cu 2 (DMPMB)] under UV irradiation (top) and the corresponding emission spectra (bottom).

elements.content: The higher-energy emissions shown by [Zn(DMPMB)] and [Cd(DMPMB)] may be confidently assigned to ligand-based π → π* electronic transitions, with no involvement of the metal centers. On the contrary, the low-energy photoluminescence emission of [Cu 2 (DMPMB)] is reasonably due to a metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) excited state, as is typical for Cu(I) complexes, in which the ligand LUMO orbitals are sufficiently low in energy to accept an excited electron from the electron-rich metal center.

On the contrary, the low-energy photoluminescence emission of [Cu  2  (DMPMB)] is reasonably due to a metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) excited state, as is typical for Cu(I) complexes, in which the ligand LUMO orbitals are sufficiently low in energy to accept an excited electron from the electron-rich metal center.

elements.content: Two novel series of thermally robust metal–organic frameworks, [M(DMPMB)] (M = Co, Zn, Cd) and [M 2 (DMPMB)] (M = Cu, Ag), were isolated by coupling the flexible, bis(pyrazolato)-based ligand 4,4′-bis((3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)­methyl)­biphenyl (H2DMPMB) and late transition metal ions. The ligand adopts an anti conformation and an exo-tetradentate coordination mode both in the isomorphous species [M(DMPMB)], inducing the formation of a 3-D architecture featuring non pervious 1-D channels, and in [Cu 2 (DMPMB)], in which corrugated 2-D layers are present. All the five materials are thermally stable and preserve their structural motif at least up to 300 °C, both under nitrogen and in air, the Cd(II) derivative decomposing only at 500 °C. While no adsorption of N2 is observed for [Cd(DMPMB)] at 77 K, the other MOFs possess estimated Langmuir specific surface areas in the range 142(4)–713(27) m2/g, suggesting that the flexible ligand has an active role in promoting specific structural modifications allowing the accommodation of the gaseous probe. Thus, due to the flexibility of the ligand, a novel, intriguing example of “porosity without pores” materials was characterized.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Two novel series of thermally robust metal-organic frameworks, [M(DMPMB)] (M = Co, Zn, Cd) and [M  2  (DMPMB)] (M = Cu, Ag), were isolated by coupling the flexible, bis(pyrazolato)-based ligand 4,4'-bis((3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)methyl)biphenyl (H2DMPMB) and late transition metal ions. The ligand adopts an anti conformation and an exo-tetradentate coordination mode both in the isomorphous species [M(DMPMB)], inducing the formation of a 3-D architecture featuring non pervious 1-D channels, and in [Cu  2  (DMPMB)], in which corrugated 2-D layers are present. All the five materials are thermally stable and preserve their structural motif at least up to 300 °C, both under nitrogen and in air, the Cd(II) derivative decomposing only at 500 °C. While no adsorption of N2 is observed for [Cd(DMPMB)] at 77 K, the other MOFs possess estimated Langmuir specific surface areas in the range 142(4)-713(27) m2/g, suggesting that the flexible ligand has an active role in promoting specific structural modifications allowing the accommodation of the gaseous probe. Thus, due to the flexibility of the ligand, a novel, intriguing example of "porosity without pores" materials was characterized.

Aiming at a better determination of the peaks positions for [Ag2(DMPMB)], data acquisitions were carried out either reducing the divergence slit aperture (down to 0.6 mm) or depositing the material as a thin film. None of these strategies allowed a successful indexing. In our opinion, the non-negligible broadening affecting the XRPD peaks severely compromises the process of unit cell determination.

H2DMPMB (0.111 g, 0.30 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of dimethylformamide in a high-pressure glass tube; Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.087 g, 0.30 mmol) was then added. The violet suspension formed was left under stirring at 130 °C for 24 h. The violet precipitate obtained was filtered off, washed twice with methanol, and then dried in vacuo. Yield: 88%. [Co(DMPMB)] is insoluble in alcohols, dimethyl sulfoxide, acetone, acetonitrile, dimethylformamide, and water. IR (cm–1): 3100–3000(vw) ν(C–Haromatic), 3000–2800(m) ν(CH3, CH2), 1504(s) ν(CC+CN). Elemental analysis calc. for C24H24CoN4 (FW = 427.41 g/mol): C, 67.44; H, 5.66; N, 13.11%. Found: C, 67.02; H, 5.63; N, 12.65%. Alternatively, compound [Co(DMPMB)] could be obtained by using cobalt(II) acetate as the source of metal ions.

Synthesis of <bold>[Zn(DMPMB)]</bold>

H2DMPMB (0.111 g, 0.30 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of dimethylformamide in a high-pressure glass tube; then, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.089 g, 0.30 mmol) was added. The white suspension formed was left under stirring at 130 °C for 24 h. The white precipitate obtained was filtered off, washed twice with methanol, and then dried in vacuo. Yield: 75%. 1 is insoluble in alcohols, dimethyl sulfoxide, acetone, acetonitrile, dimethylformamide and water. IR (cm–1): 3100–3000(vw) ν(C–Haromatic), 3000–2800(m) ν(CH3, CH2), 1508(s) ν(CC+CN). Elemental analysis calc. for C24H24N4Zn (FW = 433.86 g/mol): C, 66.44; H, 5.58; N, 12.91%. Found: C, 65.93; H, 5.58; N, 12.70%. Alternatively, compound [Zn(DMPMB)] could be obtained by using zinc(II) acetate as the source of metal ions.

Synthesis of <bold>[Cd(DMPMB)]</bold>

H2DMPMB (0.111 g, 0.30 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of dimethylformamide in a high-pressure glass tube; Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (0.092 g, 0.30 mmol) was then added, and the suspension was stirred at 130 °C for 24 h. The white precipitate obtained was filtered off, washed twice with methanol, and then dried in vacuo. Yield: 85%. [Cd(DMPMB)] is insoluble in alcohols, dimethyl sulfoxide, acetone, acetonitrile, dimethylformamide and water. IR (cm–1): 3100–3000(vw) ν(C–Haromatic), 3000–2800(m) ν(CH3, CH2), 1504(s) ν(CC+CN). Elemental analysis calc. for C24H24CdN4 (FW = 480.89 g/mol): C, 59.94; H, 5.03; N, 11.65%. Found: C, 59.56; H, 4.99; N, 11.40%. Alternatively, compound [Cd(DMPMB)] could be obtained by using cadmium(II) acetate as the source of metal ions.

Synthesis of <bold>[Cu</bold> <sub> <bold>2</bold> </sub> <bold>(DMPMB)]</bold>

H2DMPMB (0.111 g, 0.30 mmol) was dissolved in 15 mL of dimethylformamide in a high-pressure glass tube; Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O (0.070 g, 0.30 mmol) was then added. A green suspension was immediately formed, which was left under stirring at 130 °C for 24 h. The color of the suspension turned progressively from green to white. The white precipitate formed was filtered off, washed twice with methanol, and then dried in vacuo. Yield: 65%. [Cu 2 (DMPMB)] is insoluble in alcohols, dimethyl sulfoxide, acetone, acetonitrile, dimethylformamide and water. IR (cm–1): 3100–3000(vw) ν(C–Haromatic), 3000–2800(m) ν(CH3, CH2), 1510(s) ν(CC+CN). Elemental analysis calc. for C24H24Cu2N4 (FW = 495.57 g/mol): C, 58.17; H, 4.88; N, 11.31%. Found: C, 58.01; H, 4.91; N, 10.94%. Alternatively, compound [Cu 2 (DMPMB)] could be obtained by using copper(II) acetate as the source of metal ions.

Synthesis of <bold>[Ag</bold> <sub> <bold>2</bold> </sub> <bold>(DMPMB)]</bold>

H2DMPMB (92.6 mg, 0.25 mmol) was dissolved in 30 mL of methanol; separately, AgCl (71.75 mg, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in 30 mL of an aqueous solution of ammonia (30%) under gentle warming; the resulting limpid solution was added to the first one by means of a dropping funnel. The white suspension that was immediately formed was left under stirring at room temperature for 2 h. Then, the white precipitate was filtered off, washed twice with methanol, and dried in vacuo. Yield: 69%. [Ag 2 (DMPMB)] is insoluble in alcohols, dimethyl sulfoxide, acetone, acetonitrile, dimethylformamide, and water. IR (cm–1): 3100–3000(vw) ν(C–Haromatic), 3000–2800(m) ν(CH3, CH2), 1498(s) ν(CC+CN). Elemental analysis calc. for C24H24Ag2N4 (FW = 584.22 g/mol): C, 49.34; H, 4.14; N, 9.59%. Found: C, 49.78; H, 4.35; N, 9.92%.

Alternatively, compound [Ag 2 (DMPMB)] could be obtained through the addition of a hot water solution (10 mL) of silver(I) acetate (0.084 g, 0.50 mol) to a methanolic solution (20 mL) containing the ligand (0.093 g, 0.25 mol); after 2 h of stirring at room temperature, the addition of solid ammonium acetate (0.077 g, 1.00 mol) afforded [Ag 2 (DMPMB)] as a white precipitate.

cln_elements.content:
As witnessed by its TG trace (), [Cu 2 (DMPMB)] is stable up to 420 °C, the temperature at which the onset of the decomposition process is set. At the end of the thermal treatment, a dark brown residue is recovered. Also in this case the H2DMPMB-based derivative is more stable than the H2BDMPZ-containing congener, the decomposition onset of which was observed at 300 °C. The material possesses the same thermal stability also in air, as demonstrated by the VT-XRPD experiment. As highlighted by the parametric treatment of the VT-XRPD data (), thermal expansion is at work: due to the increment of both a and b, the unit cell volume increases of about 3.3% in the temperature range 30–310 °C. On the contrary, the unit cell axis c is almost unaffected by the thermal treatment, as it varies of only −0.1%: also in this case, this is the unit cell axis parallel to which the 1-D metal chains run. To clarify the origin of the variation of a and b, an overnight scan was performed at 150 °C on this material. The Rietveld refinement of the data acquired at high temperature reveals, with respect to room temperature, moderate modifications of the torsion angles involving the methylene groups () and of the geometrical parameters involving the metal center ().

Finally, as expected for a species containing a redox-active metal ion, [Ag 2 (DMPMB)] shows the lowest thermal resistance, which is nevertheless still significant, since the material does not undergo decomposition up to 300 °C. Also in this case, a black residue is recovered at the end of the decomposition process.

Photoluminescence Properties

Numerous coordination polymers containing d10 metals are well-known to exhibit interesting photoluminescence properties. In the light of this, solid state measurements at room temperature were carried out on species [Zn(DMPMB)], [Cd(DMPMB)], and [Cu 2 (DMPMB)]. Preliminary tests revealed that they respond differently when exposed to UV irradiation (Figure top): when excited at 365 nm, [Zn(DMPMB)], [Cd(DMPMB)], and [Cu 2 (DMPMB)] exhibit an intense blue, near-white, and orange luminescence emission, respectively. More in detail (Figure bottom), when excited at 365 nm, the Zn(II) derivative is characterized by a single, broad emission band in the near-UV region, centered at λmax = 440 nm. When excited at 254 nm, the Cd(II) homologous gives a single and broad emission band with a maximum at 335 nm. Finally, when excited at 365 nm, the Cu(I) species gives one broad band in the visible region, with a maximum at 597 nm.

Conclusions

Two novel series of thermally robust metal–organic frameworks, [M(DMPMB)] (M = Co, Zn, Cd) and [M 2 (DMPMB)] (M = Cu, Ag), were isolated by coupling the flexible, bis(pyrazolato)-based ligand 4,4′-bis((3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl)­methyl)­biphenyl (H2DMPMB) and late transition metal ions. The ligand adopts an anti conformation and an exo-tetradentate coordination mode both in the isomorphous species [M(DMPMB)], inducing the formation of a 3-D architecture featuring non pervious 1-D channels, and in [Cu 2 (DMPMB)], in which corrugated 2-D layers are present. All the five materials are thermally stable and preserve their structural motif at least up to 300 °C, both under nitrogen and in air, the Cd(II) derivative decomposing only at 500 °C. While no adsorption of N2 is observed for [Cd(DMPMB)] at 77 K, the other MOFs possess estimated Langmuir specific surface areas in the range 142(4)–713(27) m2/g, suggesting that the flexible ligand has an active role in promoting specific structural modifications allowing the accommodation of the gaseous probe. Thus, due to the flexibility of the ligand, a novel, intriguing example of “porosity without pores” materials was characterized.

Also in this case, a black residue is recovered at the end of the decomposition process.

Numerous coordination polymers containing d10 metals are well-known to exhibit interesting photoluminescence properties. cln_elements.content: Representation of the crystal structure of [Cd(DMPMB)]. (a) Portion of the 1-D chain of collinear metal ions bridged by the pyrazolato moieties. The hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity. (b) Portion of the 3-D architecture, visualized along c, the direction along which the metal chains run. It is possible to appreciate the rhombic motifs, the vertices of which are defined by the MN4 nodes, while the walls are decorated by the spacers. Horizontal axis, a; vertical axis, b. Carbon, gray; hydrogen, light gray; nitrogen, blue; cadmium, yellow. At the drawing level, the crystal structures of the Zn(II) and Co(II) derivatives are not distinguishable. Main bond lengths (Å) and angles (deg): Cd–N 2.24(6), 2.33(7); bridged Cd···Cd 3.895(4); N–Cd–N 106(2)-116(2). Co–N 2.06(4), 2.13(4); bridged Co···Co 3.67(1); N–Co–N 99(2)-114(2). Zn–N 2.06(4), 2.13(4); bridged Zn···Zn 3.69(1); N–Zn–N 102(2)–114(2).
